guild.description:
"For God so loved the world, that He gave His only begotten Son, that whoever believes in Him shall not perish, but have eternal life. For God did not send the Son into the world to judge the world, but that the world might be saved through Him. He who believes in Him is not judged; he who does not believe has been judged already, because he has not believed in the name of the only begotten Son of God. This is the judgment, that the Light has come into the world, and men loved the darkness rather than the Light, for their deeds were evil. For everyone who does evil hates the Light, and does not come to the Light for fear that his deeds will be exposed. But he who practices the truth comes to the Light, so that his deeds may be manifested as having been wrought in God."

May all personally encounter the presence and attention of the Lord God. 

Curiosity, questions, discussion, and prayer requests are welcome.

body:
I may be thinking of [this](https://www.churchpop.com/2016/11/03/either-catholicism-or-atheism-says-harvard-prof-who-converted/):  
>“Ultimately, I think with Newman,” Dr. Adrian Vermeule told Christina Dearduff in an interview published in the October issue of *Inside the Vatican*, referencing Bl. John Henry Newman, “and with the Notre Dame historian Brad Gregory – that there is no stable middle ground between Catholicism and atheistic materialism. One must always be traveling, or slipping unintentionally, in one direction or the other.”
body_html:
I may be thinking of this:

“Ultimately, I think with Newman,” Dr. Adrian Vermeule told Christina Dearduff in an interview published in the October issue of Inside the Vatican, referencing Bl. John Henry Newman, “and with the Notre Dame historian Brad Gregory – that there is no stable middle ground between Catholicism and atheistic materialism. One must always be traveling, or slipping unintentionally, in one direction or the other.”

body:
>**LifeSite**: *In what ways has this impacted your personal and social life?*

>**Milo**: Well, the guy I live with has been demoted to housemate, which hasn’t been easy for either of us. It helps that I can still just about afford to keep him in Givenchy and a new Porsche every year. Could be worse for him, I guess.

I was wondering if this refers to his husband — [Wiki](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milo_Yiannopoulos#Early_life_and_personal_life) thinks so:  
>In March 2021, during an interview with religious right publication LifeSite News, Yiannopoulos claimed to be "ex-gay" and stated his husband had been "demoted to housemate".[28]
body_html:
LifeSite: In what ways has this impacted your personal and social life?

Milo: Well, the guy I live with has been demoted to housemate, which hasn’t been easy for either of us. It helps that I can still just about afford to keep him in Givenchy and a new Porsche every year. Could be worse for him, I guess.

I was wondering if this refers to his husband — Wiki thinks so:

In March 2021, during an interview with religious right publication LifeSite News, Yiannopoulos claimed to be "ex-gay" and stated his husband had been "demoted to housemate".[28]

body:
I actually agree. I was a violent kid growing up (it was in my genes).

My dad sat me down right before I was 18, had a talk with me. He told me I can't punch people in the face any time situations get heated when I turn 18 because my ass will go to jail. He explained it much better than that but that is the summary. Then I realized, holy shit, I need to change what I'm doing or I'm going to jail.

So I stopped getting into fights. I haven't been in a fight since then. Years. Just because I had a parent who cared enough to tell me to stop being a hot-head. 

But it takes both to make a change like that - good parenting and a kid who is willing to make changes to their behavior. 

I feel that is what is missing from many of these folks: they never got the talk from their parents about self-control and/or the kid never thought to make changes to their behavior. When both are present, your kids group up to be well-adjusted adults.

body:
You just described my ex to perfection. Her parents gave her anything she wanted and she almost never got disciplined. Her brother was. Her brother is the one that was a well-adjusted adult, hard working, and successful even at 21 (when he was still working on his masters of accounting). 

Her parents raised her to be a narcissist even though she didn't want to be. She was just forced/pushed in that direction by bad parenting. She didn't pull her head out of her ass until I broke up with her and she had to survive on her own and work on her own in a job. Then she matured quickly. Became an adult. Now she's a decent person and can be tolerated.

Shitty parents, man. They are ruining kids especially girls. Tough love works. Tell your daughters "No." And if they throw a tantrum, don't give in. Put them in timeout. Bam. Huge portion of America's problems are solved by better raising daughters.

parent.body:
I actually agree. I was a violent kid growing up (it was in my genes).

My dad sat me down right before I was 18, had a talk with me. He told me I can't punch people in the face any time situations get heated when I turn 18 because my ass will go to jail. He explained it much better than that but that is the summary. Then I realized, holy shit, I need to change what I'm doing or I'm going to jail.

So I stopped getting into fights. I haven't been in a fight since then. Years. Just because I had a parent who cared enough to tell me to stop being a hot-head. 

But it takes both to make a change like that - good parenting and a kid who is willing to make changes to their behavior. 

I feel that is what is missing from many of these folks: they never got the talk from their parents about self-control and/or the kid never thought to make changes to their behavior. When both are present, your kids group up to be well-adjusted adults.
